description: Theory students, faculty and visiting scholars present their current research.

title: SEM ORCHESTRATION
description: Instrumental families of the orchestra.

title: SEM ORCHESTRATION
description: Writing for full orchestra.

title: GRAD COMPOSITION
description: Individual instruction in composition.

title: COMPUT MUS SYN/COMP
description: First quarter of general purpose computing for computer music applications. Topics include: introduction to the UNIX operating system and the vi editor, music synthesis using C-based computer programs and score input programs.

title: COMPUT MUS SYN/COMP
description: Second quarter of a three-quarter sequence will concentrate on computer music instrument design using C-based music software and exploring applications of frequency modulation, amplitude modulation, additive/subtractive synthesis, digital signal processing and computer music composition.

title: INTR. ELECTR. MUSIC
description: An introductory course on electroacoustic music. Historical perspective. An alysis of different types of electronic/acousmatic/mixed compositions. Intr oduction to different techniques of sound transformation.

title: REAL-TIME SYN/COMP
description: First quarter of a three-quarter sequence course will concentrate on multi-track recording, mixing, digital signal processing using micro-computers and special purpose dsp equipment.

title: REAL-TIME SYN/COMP
description: Second quarter of a three-quarter sequence course will concentrate on digital synthesis (primarily frequency modulation, simple and complex; but also amplitude modulation and additive synthesis) using micro-computers, digital synthesizers and processing equipment.

title: REAL-TIME SYN/COMP
description: Third quarter of a three-quarter sequence course will concentrate on real-time computer music composition with micro-computer and digital synthesis/processing equipment.

title: SPC TPCS ELEC MUS
description: Advanced topics in computer music composition, synthesis, and   digital signal processing.

title: INTR VIS MUS
description: Introductory course on Visual Music. Historical perspective. Introduction t o Final Cut Pro, After Effects, Cinema 4D and other visual music compositio n software.  Several short exercises will be required during the quarter.

title: VIS MUS COMP
description: Visual Music composition. Mixing, synthesis, animation, sound-image integra tion. An original Visual Music composition is required after the end of the course.

title: ELMNTRY VOICE I
description: Elementary voice lessons at beginning level. Placement in Music A, B, or C will be determined by the instructor after an audition.

title: ELMNTRY VOICE II
description: Elementary voice lessons designed for those with a small amount of vocal experience.

title: ELMNTRY VOICE III
description: Elementary voice lessons designed for those who have significant vocal training and experience.

title: SOFTW DEV COMP
description: First quarter of a course devoted to composition by means of   software. Ex isting software of this nature will be   demonstrated, discussed and where possible, used by students   to generate compositions.

title: SOFTW OPEN FORUM
description: Software Open Forum involves the ongoing development by   enrolled students of software for music composition and   processing as directed by the inst ructor, to be eventually put   on the MAT and Music Department websites for free downloading   by students, faculty and others.

title: CNT CMP TCH (INST)
description: Study of different compositional techniques based on the analysis of pieces from the repertoire. Rhythm manipulation, harmonic contents, formal aspect s, integration between instruments and electronics, extended techniques, ge sture control, etc. A short paper explaining the application of one or more of these techniques in an original composition is required after the end o f the course.

title: CNT CMP TCH (ELEC)
description: Study of different compositional techniques based on sound objects transfor mations. Analysis of pieces from the repertoire. Synthesis, recording, mixi ng, sound object transformation techniques, spatialization. An original 5-8 min acousmatic/electronic music composition is required after the end of t he course.

title: CNT CMP TCH (EL/MX)
description: Composition class in electroacoustic music (acousmatic/electronic/mixed). A n original 5-8 min acousmatic/electronic/mixed music composition is require d after the end of the course.

title: CANON AND FUGUE
description: A detailed study of Bach's canons and fugues, including invertible counterp oint, stretto, triple and quadruple counterpoint, as well as extensions by later and contemporary composers. Extensive compositional exercises require d.

title: ADV HARMONY
description: Study of chorale, elaborated chorale, lied and other harmonization techniqu es. Compositional exercises required during the quarter.

title: CANON AND FUGUE
description: A detailed study of Bach's canons and fugues, including invertible counterpoint, stretto, triple and quadruple counterpoint, as well as extensions by later and contemporary composers. Extensive compositional exercises required.

title: APPLIED INSTRUCTION
description: Applied vocal or instrumental instruction for graduate   students other than in the performance emphasis discipline of   MM and DMA degree programs.

title: WORLD MUSIC INSTR.
description: Applied instruction in non-Western instruments: the Indian   sitar, the Middle Eastern `ud (lute) and nay (end-blown   flute), and Middle Eastern percussion.

title: MM/DMA PERF INST
description: Applied instruction in the performance emphasis discipline (MM piano accompanying: instruction in piano) of MM and DMA degree   programs.

title: PRACTM WORLD MUSIC
description: Individual or group instruction in non-Western instruments:   the Indian sitar, the Middle Eastern `ud (lute) and nay   (end-blown flute), and Middle Eastern percussion.

title: PRACTM WORLD MUSIC
description: Individual or group instruction in non-Western instruments: the Indian sitar, the   Middle Eastern `ud (lute) and nay (end-blown flute), and Middle Eastern   percussion.

title: FIELD & LAB ETHNO
description: The development and execution of field research designs. Practical field ex perience using various techniques of data collection and management, includ ing music recording, photography, filming, questionaires, and interviewing. The use and interpretation of standard and innovative laboratory methods f or processing data, including computer analysis.

title: SEM ETHNOMUSICOLOGY
description: A graduate seminar examining special problems, current theories, analytic procedures, and recent innovations in ethnomusicology.

title: DASTGAH
description: An examination of the system of melodic modes (dastgah) that governs practice in the   Persian/Iranian music. Emphasis given to theoretical issues (scales, intervals, and melodic   progressions) and analysis of standard repertoire. Students will receive introductory   lessons on Persian instruments(the setar and tar).

title: WORLD MUSIC GAMELAN
description: Applied instruction in Gamelan instruments and the Tarling musical style of Indonesia.

title: MAQAM
description: Applied instruction in non-Western instruments: the Arabic   maqam, the system of melodic modes used in traditional   Arabic music.

title: NAY
description: Applied instruction in non-Western instruments: the Middle-  Eastern nay (end-blown flute).

title: OUD
description: Applied instruction in the Middle Eastern oud (lute).

title: MID EAST PERCUSSION
description: Applied instruction in non-Western instruments: Middle   Eastern percussion.

title: WORLD MUSIC INSTR.
description: Applied instruction in a non-Western instrument.

title: ORCH CONDUCTING
description: Advanced conducting techniques, score reading and analysis, general rehearsal procedures and repertoire for each type of ensemble: symphony, chamber orchestra and large vocal/instrumental ensembles.

title: CHORAL CONDUCTING
description: Advanced conducting techniques, score reading and analysis, rehearsal techniques and repertoire for vocal and choral ensembles.

title: CHORAL TECHNIQUES
description: Aspects of choral techniques, including: development of concert programs an d rehearsal plans, rehearsal procedures, types of vocal ensembles and seati ng configurations, acoustical considerations, performance and recording pro cedures, long-term programming and artistic development, social and organiz ation aspects of vocal ensemble.

title: SCORE READING
description: A practical survey of score-reading of selected orchestral scores of the eighteenth, nineteenth, and twentieth centuries including a detailed study of the necessary transcriptions and their relationship to the various clefs.

title: SCORE READING
description: A practical survey of score-reading of selected orchestral scores of the eighteenth, nineteenth, and twentieth centuries including a detailed study of the necessary transcriptions and their relationship to the various clefs.

title: ACCOMPANYING T & R
description: Emphasizes advanced accompaniment techniques, the intensive study of the French and German song cycle, secco recitative, and orchestral score-reading.

title: ACCOMPANYING T & P
description: Emphasizes advanced accompaniment techniques, the intensive study of the French and German song cycle, secco recitative, and orchestral score-reading.

title: ACCOMPANYING T & P
description: Emphasizes advanced accompaniment techniques, the intensive study of the French and German song cycle, secco recitative, and orchestral score-reading.

title: CARILLON
description: Applied instruction on Carillon (bells in bell tower)   performance.

title: INTERMEDIATE VOICE
description: Intermediate voice lessons.

title: SEMINAR IN THEORY
description: Analysis and theory of atonal music.

title: SEMINAR IN THEORY
description: Analysis and theory of twelve-tone music.

title: SEMINAR IN HISTORY
description: History of early music theory.

title: SEMINAR IN THEORY
description: History of music theory from Rameau to Schenker.

title: SEM SCHENKER ANLYS
description: Readings in the theory of Schenkerian analysis. Basic analytical techniques.

title: SEM SCHENKER ANLYS
description: Advanced readings in Schenkerian theory. Analysis of large forms.

title: VIOLA ORCH REP
description: The study of the entire standard orchestral repertoire for   viola and audition procedures.

title: ACTING FOR SINGERS
description: Study of techniques and practice of acting on the stage for singers as preparation for performing operatic roles, in lecture and workshop settings.

title: VOCAL/INST COACHING
description: Musical preparation of vocal or instrumental works.

title: COMPOSITION FORUM
description: A forum for the presentation and discussion of new works by students, facul ty, and guest composers.

title: OPERA/SONG REP
description: A detailed study of operatic literature and concert literature (Lieder, melodies, songs, and pieces with instruments). The interpretation of vocal music as a preparation for performance.

title: KEYBOARD LITERATURE
description: A study of the history and literature of keyboard music from the baroque th rough the twentieth century.

title: MUSIC COGNITION
description: Surveys research in music cognition and introduces empirical methods for st udying music. Topics include music perception and cognition, memory and exp ectation, emotion and meaning, emergence and development of skills and perf ormance, perspectives from social and cultural psychology, among others.

title: TUNING/TEMPERAMENT
description: The course surveys a number of tuning systems around the world, including those of ancient Greece, Europe, India, China, the Arab Middle East, Turkey, and Indonesia. The mathematical, aesthetic, and symbolic basis of each system will be considered.

title: ARAB MODES-MAQAMAT
description: Examination of the system of melodic modes (maqamat) governing present-day melodic practice in the eastern Arab world. Emphasis given to theoretical issues (quarter tones, tetrachordal structures, theories of intonation), analysis of pieces in the repertoire, and procedures governing improvisation.

title: SOUND COLOR
description: "Sound color" refers to the quality or timbre of musical sound, whether instrumental, vocal, or synthetic. This course investigates timbre's special perceptual and cognitive qualities, as well as its unique expressive power in music.

title: TONAL ANALYSIS REV
description: An in-depth review of elements and procedures of 18th- and   19th-century harmony, aimed at analyzing conventional   formal types (binary, ternary, rondo, sonata, sonata-rondo,   concerto).

title: OTHER ETHNO ISSUES
description: A study of other cultural issues in ethnomusicology. Specific   topics vary by quarter and will be announced in advanced by   the department.

title: MUSIC & TOURISM
description: Students read folklore, anthropology, tourism studies, musicology, and ethnomusicology in an attempt to develop theories for interpreting the impact of tourism on music locally and globally.

title: FILM MUSIC COGNITN
description: A consideration of film music as a medium of communication between the director, composer, music supervisor, editors, performers and the audience. Emphasis given to cognitive psychological theories of meaning in terms of structure and affect in audio/visual contexts. Students are required to propose and complete an experiment in film music cognition.

title: MUSIC AS MEDIA
description: Recorded media are central to the way we hear, create, exchange and experience music in contemporary social life. Topics include the early uses of the phonograph, recording studios, file-sharing, online musical exchange and roles of technological media in globalizing cultures.

title: PERFORMANCE STUDIES
description: An exploration of the contemporary field of performance studies, relevant for students in all areas of music study. Inherently interdisciplinary, subjects encompass production, reception, technologies, embodiment, politics, geographies, identities, and virtualities.

title: UMM KULTHUM
description: Analysis of the music, life and times of the predominant Arab   singer of the twentieth century. Individual projects may focus   on music or text analysis, issues of gender, nationalism,   agency, performance, practice and investigation of related   arts (film, novels, etc.).

title: MUSICOLOGY SEMINAR
description: Graduate Seminar in Musicology. Topics will vary.

title: SEM MUS 20TH CENT
description: Graduate seminar in music of the twentieth century.

description: Intermediate violin lessons.

title: STDS MUSIC THEORY
description: Selected topics in musical analysis.

title: MUSICAL ACOUSTICS
description: Consideration of the relationships between acoustics, perception and music. Emphasis on the physical and psychophysiological bases for tonality, dynamics, timbre and rhythm. Additional focus on the vibrational properties of musical instruments and features of digital recording and playback.

title: SEM MUS CRITICISM
description: Investigation of important critical writing in music from the early ninetee nth century to the present with study of related works in the field of aest hetics. Analysis of the scope and impact of criticism in the musical life o f each period.

title: STUDIES ETHNOMUSICO
description: An introduction to the field of ethnomusicology using theories and methods derived from the social sciences and humanities. Topic areas to include transcription and analysis, musicians, musical instruments, music acculturation, and the function of music in society.

description: An introduction to the field of ethnomusicology using theories and methods derived from the social sciences and humanities. Topic areas to include transcription and analysis, musicians, musical instruments, music acculturation, and the function of music in society.

title: MUSIC OF INDIA
description: A survey of music traditions of the Indian subcontinent from classical to folk and popular. Emphasis given to the position of music in Hindu philosophy, the role of music in society, musical instruments, and modal and rythmic structures (raga and tala).

title: MUSIC IN MOD JAPAN
description: This course explores music and culture in modern Japan. What kind of society do we hear in its diverse mix of sounds and musical practices? We explore this question through traditional genres, national politics, and transnational exchanges of popular media.

title: POL TATRA MTN CULT
description: The Tatras are the home of a distinct folk culture, including music based on polyphonic singing and violin ensembles. Course investigates the present day music from this region and its history, and examines the influence of tourism and ethnography on the music culture.

title: AMERICAN FOLK MUSIC
description: The study of English-language American folk music, using mixed-media tools for learning. The focus is on string band music often associated with Appalachia and usually called "oldtime," and the the distinct but related styles of bluegrass and country.

description: Introduces students to ways of studying music as a cultural   practice situated in society. Methods are drawn from   musicology, ethnomusicology, history, anthropology, and   sociology. Students will be taught to think critically about   music as a universal human expression.

description: Acquaints students with different approaches to writing and   speaking about music of many traditions. The works of   performers, critics, music theorists, ethnographers,   musicologists, and historians will all be represented in the   selection of assigned readings.

title: STRUCTURES OF MUSIC
description: Looking at a variety of music traditions from different parts   of the world, the class will survey varying approaches to   issues of compositional structure, rhythm, intonation, scales, etc. The   class will have listening and practical components.

Seminar will be organized as a workshop in which all students will present portions of their writing for discussion. As tailored to each students project, we will discuss a number of dissertation writing challenges and learn how to self-edit and critically evaluate effective thesis writing.

description: Preparation of sophomore composition portfolio.

title: READINGS IN MUSIC
description: Critical review and discussion of related topics in musicology, ethnomusicology, composition, theory, or performance.

title: INTRO MUS RESEARCH
description: Independent research under the guidance of a faculty member in the department. Course offers exceptional students the opportunity to undertake independent research or work in a research group in topics in musicology, ethnomusicology, composition, theory, or performance.

title: INTRO MUS RESEARCH
description: Independent research under the guidance of a faculty member in the department. Course offers exceptional students the opportunity to undertake independent research or work in a research group in topics in musicology, ethnomusicology, composition, theory, or performance.

title: WIND ENSEMBLE
description: Masterworks of the literature for ensembles smaller than orchestral or full band scoring. Although the basic ensembles feature winds, both strings and percussion are utilized.

title: UCSB CHAMBER CHOIR
description: A select ensemble of voice majors and non-majors, the Chamber Choir prepares musicians for professional ensemble work and offers advanced study in choral literature, techniques, styles and interpretation covering five centuries of choral repertoire.

title: UCSB LUMINA
description: This chorus studies and performs the main repertory for treble voices, from Renaissance to 21st Century.  Occasionally undertakes collaboration with o ther UCSB choirs and community entities.  No audition required.

title: SINGING GAUCHOS
description: The UCSB Singing Gauchos is a tenor and bass choir performing fine choral l iterature representative of various style periods and vocal techniques from the global choral tradition.  Regular performances on and off campus.

title: OPERA WORKSHOP
description: Participation in opera scenes.

title: OPERA PRODUCTION
description: Participation in annual opera production.

title: OPERA OUTREACH
description: The Opera Outreach Program is the touring performance of a staged opera   s cene by advanced voice students from UCSB's Department of Music, presented to various high schools and community choirs in the Santa Barbara Area an d   beyond.    Students (and their understudies) will learn and rehearse an operatic scene   in the first 5-7 weeks of the Spring Quarter. Once they a re memorized,   staged, and choreographed, the outreach performances (in fu ll costume/make-  up) begin in the last weeks of the quarter.

title: ENSEMBL CONTEMP MUS
description: Reading sessions and preparation for performance of contemporary music. There will be one or two concerts each quarter. Includes departmental scholarship players, and is open to composers who also perform.

title: PIANO ENSEMBLE
description: Piano duets (1 piano, 4 hands) and duos (2 pianos) in separate   sections.

title: ORCHESTRA
description: UCSB Chamber Orchestra performs pieces from the traditional chamber orchest ra repertoire, as well as more contemporary pieces for chamber orchestra.

title: FLUTE CHOIR
description: The flute choir studies flute literature in depth, perfects technique and interpretation, employs the complete flute family of bass, alto flutes and piccolos. Prepares ensemble for public performances each quarter.

title: CHAMBER MUS ENSMBL
description: Chamber music ensemble.

title: BRASS QUINTET
description: Participation in scholarship brass quintet.

title: BRASS ORCH REP
description: Intensive exploration of staple brass orchestral repertoire, emphasizing the works of important 19th and 20th century composers. Classes include rehearsal sessions, guided listening and analysis, mock auditions, resume and taped audition preparation.

title: HORN ENSEMBLE
description: Horn ensemble.

title: CLARINET CHOIR
description: Clarinet choir.

title: JAZZ ENSEMBLE
description: Instruction in interpretation and performance of jazz music. Improvisation is stressed.

title: PERCUSSION ENSEMBLE
description: Rehearsal and performance of standard percussion ensemble   literature. Instruction of appropriate playing techniques for   standard and exotic percussion instruments.

title: VIOLIN ENSEMBLE
description: A course designed for violin students which explores   repertoire for multiple violins.

title: AMERICAN FOLK MUSIC
description: The study of English-language folk music, emanating from the southeastern United States, focusing on the string band music usually called "old-time," and the distinct but related style of "bluegrass." These traditions are related to commerical genres known as "country."

title: INDIV COMPOSITION
description: Individual instruction in composition, usually for one hour per week.

title: ANALYSIS- MATERIALS
description: Small group instruction in theoretical subjects (harmony, composition, orchestration, etc.).

title: ANALYSIS- FORMS
description: Small group instruction in musical forms and their development.

title: CCS MUS SPEC TOPICS
description: Individual or small group instruction in selected subjects related to the s tudy of Music Composition, including but not limited to individual composer s and their works, special compositional techniques, performance projects, and topics in technological applications to music.

title: ALGORITHMIC COMP
description: A formalized journey into the basics of algorithmic composition, using Max/ MSP as a tool to aid the artist and engineer alike. We explore how simple a lgorithmic models can provide intriguing sonic results across all genres. T hese methods are not only useful for schematic problem solving but can also be good for expanding musical and creative thinking.

title: WRITING FOR PIANO
description: Although one of the most commonly used instruments, piano can still be one of the trickiest instruments to master compositionally. In this course, we cover decades of styles, writing for solo piano, piano in chamber music, pi ano duo, & piano in orchestra. We also cover piano reductions and arranging for piano. Most assignments are small compositions and a final composition project.

title: COMPUTER APPLICATNS
description: Applications of the various campus computers to problems in music.

title: MUSIC COLLOQUIUM
description: Students receiving credit will present talks in their fiel on material arranged in consultation with the instructor. Credit assigned by the instructor will reflect the extent and quality of participation.

title: INDEPENDENT STUDIES
description: Serious independent study in music with consenting faculty   member.

title: GROUP STUDIES
description: Student-directed discussion and study in a variety of   subjects within Mus ic Composition.

title: Placeholder
description: This is a placeholder for a major elective course of your choosing

title: SHORT INTRO TO PHIL
description: An introductory course in western philosophy.

title: ETHICS
description: AN EXAMINATION OF THE FUNDAMENTAL CONCEPTS, THEORIES, AND PROBLEMS OF MORAL OR POLITICAL PHILOSOPHY.

title: THEORY OF KNOWLEDGE
description: Investigates fundamental questions surrounding the nature   of human knowle dge and human justification, such as: What   do I know? What am I justified in believing? What is it to   know something? What is it to hold a justifi ed belief?

title: PHIL OF LANGUAGE
description: Introduction to philosophical problems and theories concerning the nature o f language. Topics typically include the notion of linguistic structure, th eories of meaning and reference, names and descriptions, the relations betw een languages and thought, necessity and analytic truty, and conversational norms.

title: PHILOSOPHY OF MIND
description: Discussion of some central questions about the mind: are   people identical to their bodies? What is it to feel,   believe, or desire something? What distinguishes   intelligent thinking from a computer's activities? What is the connection between language and thought?

title: METAPHYSICS
description: Introduction to the philosophical study of the most general and fundamental features of reality. Topics vary, but may include universals, particulars, identity and individuation, substance, the nature of persons, causation, a nd the nature of time.

title: INTRO PHIL SCIENCE
description: An introduction to the philosophical analysis of the concepts and   methods of science, treating such topics as: explanation, confirmation,   causatio n, scientific laws, the interpretation, meaning and reference   of scientif ic theories, theory reduction and theory change, and   scientific revolutio ns.

title: CONTINENTAL PHIL
description: A survey of recent continental philosophy.

title: PHIL OF RELIGION
description: A study of some of the following topics: religious language, the existence and nature of god, the problem of evil, religious experience, religion and morality, the rationality of religious belief.

title: MEANING & REFERENCE
description: An examination of the classical theories of meaning and reference: John Stuart Mill, Gottlob Frege, Bertrand Russell, and the theory of direct reference. Investigation of solutions to the classical puzzles of meaning and reference.

title: POLITICL PHILOSOPHY
description: Analysis of fundamental political conceptions; the state, sovereignty, political obligation, natural rights, natural law, etc.

title: THEORIES OF JUSTICE
description: An examination, in detail, of one or more influential philosophical theories of justice.

title: PHIL OF SCIENCE
description: Analysis of the interrelated functions of scientific   theories, models, la ws, experiments, and observational   procedures in relation to the goals of explanation,   prediction, control, and understanding. Problems of   induct ion and the logic of confirmation.

title: PHIL OF SCIENCE
description: What is science? How does it differ from non-science? Course examines both the history of science and the history of philosophy of science in an effor t to discover just what science is and what it has to offer.

title: PHIL OF PHYSICS
description: Emphasizes the role that philosophical considerations played in both the ev olution and actual practice of science. The major emphasis is on the creati on and development of the watersheds of twentieth-century physics: relativi ty and quantum mechanics.

title: PHIL OF SPACE/TIME
description: Is space a thing or a series of relations holding between objects? Does tim e pass differently for different observers, or in different parts of the un iverse? Consideration of these and other questions lead to an examination o f contemporary physics.

title: PHIL OF QM
description: Examines the history of the development of quantum mechanics, focusing on t he philosophical conundrums that arose from the tortured process of finding a theory that "worked." This is done at the conceptual level, with minimal reliance on mathematical techniques.

title: FEMINIST PHILOSOPHY
description: In this course, we examine philosophical approaches to feminism and feminis t issues. Topics covered may include inequality in the workplace and in fam ily structures; global feminism; objectification; pornography; and prostitu tion.

title: FREEDOM/DETERMINISM
description: Determinism is the doctrine that the laws of nature plus   the past necessi tate the future. Is determinism compatible   with the view that we often ac t freely and are often   morally responsible for what we do?

title: ADV APPLIED ETHICS
description: Advanced topics in applied ethics, such as the ethics of war; the ethics of procreation; and the ethics of how we treat animals.

title: HIST POLIT THOUGHT
description: A study of one or more important figures from the history of political thought.

title: MORAL PSYCHOLOGY
description: An examination of the nature of desires, emotions, the imagination and other aspects of human psychology, and of the ways these bear on the moral evaluation of people and actions.

title: CONTEMP PHILOSOPHY
description: Systematic investigation of topics drawn from contemporary analytic or continental philosophy.

title: AESTHETIC THEORY
description: A study of some major works in the philosophy of art from Plato to the present, with emphasis on the development and analysis of the basic concepts employed in criticism of the arts.

title: NORMATIVE ETHICS
description: An examination of what makes actions morally right or wrong and people morally good or bad.

title: META-ETHICS
description: An examination of problems concerning the meaning and justification of mora l judgments.

title: HIST ETHICS
description: A study of one or more historically important moral philosophers.

title: ADV TOP PHIL RELIG
description: Advanced topics in the philosophy of religion. Specific subject matter is s elected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department office before each quarter.

title: PHILOSOPHY OF LAW
description: An introduction to some of the main issues generated by the philosophical question, "What is law?" In what sense is conduct made obligatory by the existence of law?  What, if any, is the relationship between law and morals?  What are rules? What does it mean to say that a rule exists? Do courts really apply rules or merely pretend to do so?

title: ADV PHIL LAW
description: Study of advanced topics in the philosophy of law.

title: PUNISHMENT & RESPON
description: An examination of some of the philosophical problems of punishment and responsibility: The rationale of punishment and the legal doctrine of Mensrea; the analysis of conditions of responsibility, relations between punishment, responsibility, retribution, guilt, shame, etc.

title: PHIL IN LITERATURE
description: Introduction to major problems at the intersection of   philosophy and lite rature.  Issues addressed may include   philosophical assessments of litera ture, authorship and   interpretation, truth in fiction, significance of li terary   works and form for philosophy; texts include imaginative   literat ure and philosophical essays.

title: PHIL OF ECONOMICS
description: An introduction to conceptual and methodological issues surrounding modern economics. Topics may include the scientific status of economics, the use o f economic models, the connection between economics and moral theory, and n otions of preference, choice, well-being, and rationality in economics.

title: ACTION THEORY
description: An examination of philosophical topics connected with human action, e.g. the role of intentions and desires in the explanation and justification of action and the nature of practical reason.

title: ADV ETHICAL THEORY
description: Advanced topics in ethical theory. Specific subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department office before each quarter.

title: ADV THRY KNOWLEDGE
description: Advanced topics in theory of knowledge. Specific subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department office before each quarter.

title: ADV PHIL LANGUAGE
description: Specific subject matter selected by the instructor. Descriptions available in the department office before each quarter.

title: ADV PHIL OF MIND
description: Advanced topics in philosophy of mind. Specific subject matter is selected the instructor and descriptions are available in the department office befo re each quarter.

title: ADV METAPHYSICS
description: Advanced topics in metaphysics. Specific subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department before each qua rter.

title: PRE-SOCRATICS
description: A study of the pre-Socratic philosophers.

title: PLATO
description: The philosophy of Plato.

title: ARISTOTLE
description: The philosophy of Aristotle.

title: SOCRATES
description: Socrates and his place in Greek philosophy.  The course focuses mainly on P lato's Socratic dialogues but may also treat Socrates' predecessors (princi pally the Sophists) and contemporary views of Socrates in other authors.

title: HELLENISTIC PHIL
description: An examination of the thought of major Greek philosophers of the Hellenistic period.

title: DESCARTES
description: The philosophy of Descartes.

title: SPINOZA
description: The philosophy of Spinoza.

title: LEIBNIZ
description: The philosophy of Leibniz.

title: LOCKE
description: The philosophy of John Locke.

title: BERKELEY
description: The philosophy of Berkeley.

title: HUME
description: The philosophy of David Hume.

title: KANT
description: An examination of the philosophy of Kant with special attention to the critique of pure reason.

title: FREGE
description: An examination of the work of the German philosopher and   logician, Gottlo b Frege.

title: HIST PHILOSOPHERS
description: Examination of historical philosophers beyond those covered in Philosophy 106 and 151-166.

title: PHILOSOPHICAL PSYCH
description: An examination of some of the concepts of the mind such as those of desire, intention, action, perception, sensation, and the unconcious.

title: BEGIN MODERN LOGIC
description: An introduction to the concepts and methods of moder symbolic logic. Emphas is is placed on problems of translating english expressions into logical sy mbols and on the development of skills in using the formal proof procedures of sentential and predicate logic.

title: INTERMED MODRN LOGI
description: Further application and development of the predicate calculus, including th e calculi of identity and description. An introduction to the metalogical q uestions of completeness, consistency, and decidability.

title: ADV MODERN LOGIC
description: Topics from the theory of formal systems, set theory, recursive function th eory, and automata theory.

title: PHILOSOPHICAL LOGIC
description: Topics in logical theory and the philosophy of logic: intensional logic and other non-standard logics (such as modal logic); discussion of results of m odern logic and their philosophical implications.

title: THEORY OF VALUE
description: Study of theories of the nature and structure of the good and of value judgments generally.

title: INTERN PHILOSOPHY
description: Practical experience and application of analytical skills learned in philosophy as interns with agencies and business. Periodic and final reports required under faculty direction.

title: SR HONORS THESIS
description: A continuous two-quarter research and writing tutorial designed for senior honors majors. The first term will be spent mainly in selecting and researching a topic for the thesis.

title: SR HONORS THESIS
description: A continuous two-quarter research and writing tutorial designed for senior honors majors. The second term will be spent mainly in the writing of the thesis.

title: SEN PROJECT ETHICS
description: A research and writing tutorial on some topic relevant to issues in ethics and public policy. A written proposal of the project must be approved by the undergraduate adviser and the instructor.

title: INDEPENDENT STUDIES
description: A written statement of the proposed program of study must be   presented to the instructor for his or her approval before the   student signs up for the course.

title: INDEP RESRCH ASSIST
description: Course work shall consist of faculty supervised research.

title: CONTINENTAL PHIL
description: A survey of recent continental philosophy.

title: HISTORY PHILOSOPHY
description: From Thales to Aristotle.

title: HISTORY PHILOSOPHY
description: From Medievals to Rationalists.

title: HISTORY PHILOSOPHY
description: From the Empiricists and Kant.

description: Study at the graduate level of topics in the philosophy of religion.

description: An examination of the classical theories of meaning and reference: John Stuart Mill, Gottlob Frege, Bertrand Russell, and the theory of direct reference. Solutions to the classical puzzles of meaning and reference are investigated.

description: A study at the graduate level of topics in th theory of knowledge.

description: A study at the graduate level of topics in metaphysics.

description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of the pre-Socratic era.

title: PLATO
description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Plato.

title: ARISTOTLE
description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Aristotle.

title: SOCRATES
description: A study at the graduate level of Socrates and his place in Greek philosophy .  The course focuses mainly on Plato's Socratic dialogues but may also tre at Socrates' predecessors (principally the Sophists) and contemporary views of Socrates in other authors.

title: HELLENISTIC PHIL
description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of the Hellenistic philosophers.

title: DESCARTES
description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Descartes.

title: SPINOZA
description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Spinoza.

title: LEIBNIZ
description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Leibniz.

title: BERKELEY
description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Berkeley.

title: HUME
description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Hume.

title: KANT
description: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Kant.

title: FREGE
description: An examination of the work of the german philosopher and   logician, Gottlo b Frege.

title: HIST PHILOSOPHERS
description: Examination of historical philosophers beyond those covered in Philosophy 106 and 151-166.

title: PHILOSOPHICAL PSYCH
description: A study at the graduate level of selected problems in philosophical psychology.

title: BEG SYMBOLIC LOGIC
description: An introduction to symbolic logic at the graduate level.

title: INT SYMBOLIC LOGIC
description: A continuation of the study of symbolic logic.

title: ADV SYMBOLIC LOGIC
description: An advanced study of symbolic logic.

title: PHILOSOPHICAL LOGIC
description: Topics in logical theory and the philosophy of logic: intensional logic and other non-standard logics (such as modal logic); discussion of results of m odern logic and their philosophical implications.

title: SEMINAR IN ETHICS
description: Graduate seminar in ethics. Specific subject matter is   selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in   the department office before each quarter.

title: SEM EPISTEMOLOGY
description: Graduate seminar in epistemology. Specific subject matter is   selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in   the department office before each quarter.

title: SEM PHILOSOPHY LANG
description: Graduate seminar in the philosophy of language. Specific   subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions   are available in the department office before each quarter.

title: SEM PHILOSOPHY MIND
description: Graduate seminar in the philosophy of mind. Specific subject   matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are   available in the department office before each quarter.

title: SEM IN METAPHYSICS
description: Graduate seminar in metaphysics. Specific subject matter is   selected by theinstructor and descriptions are available in   the department office before each quarter.

title: SEM HISTORY PHIL
description: Graduate seminar in the history of philosophy. Specific   subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions   are available in the department office before each quarter.

title: SEM PHIL OF LOGIC
description: Graduate seminar in the philosophy of logic. Specific subject   matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are   available in the department office before each quarter.

title: SEM PHIL SCIENCE
description: Graduate seminar in the philosophy of science. Specific   subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions   are available in the department office before each quarter.

title: CRITICAL THINKING
description: Practical reasoning, argumentation, and the analysis of language as instruments of sound thinking in everyday life.

title: INTRO ETHICS
description: An examination, at an introductory level, of such ethical issues as: why be moral, moral relativism, the nature of virtues and vices; and possibly consideration of practical ethical problems such as abortion or war.

title: APP TEACH IN PHIL
description: A teaching practicum involving the study and development of effective teaching techniques in philosophy. Each student will be responsible for and teach a class section in an undergraduate course in philosophy. One meeting per week with instructor and one or more discussion section meetings, and attendance in the lecture of the assigned course are required.

title: T A TRAINING
description: Instructional training. Orientation in professional conduct and responsibilities; observation of student's teaching (in the form of faculty visits or videotaping) and follow-up conferences; discussion of teaching evaluations and workshops on pedagogical problems.

title: FIRST YR PROSEMINAR
description: Special seminar for first-year graduate students in Philosophy.

title: DIR READ & RESEARCH
description: A written proposal must be approved by the instructor and department chair.

title: IND STD MA/PHD EXAM
description: Individual preparation for the doctoral qualifying examination.

title: PH D DISS PREP
description: Ph.D. dissertation research and preparation.

title: BIO-MED ETHICS
description: An examination of philosophical thinking about moral issues raised by the practice of medicine. Traditional ethical theories and problems will serve as background to, and in turn be illuminated by, such issues as informed consent, paternalism, abortion, euthanasia, and genetic engineering.

title: BASIC PHYSICS
description: Introduction to classical mechanics for students in   engineering and the p hysical sciences. Measurement, units,   and foundations of physics; vectors ; kinematics; circular   motion; forces, mass, and Newton's laws; center of mass;   momentum; work and energy; conservation laws; collisions;   rotati onal kinematics.

title: CONCEPTS OF PHYSICS
description: A survey of important concepts in physics for the non-science major. The contents will vary depending on the interests of the students and instructor.

title: METHODS THEOR PHYS
description: Linear Algebra: Vector spaces, operators, spectral decomposition. Topics ma y include Sturm-Liouville equations, special functions. Fourier series and Fourier transforms, Dirac delta-function.

title: METHODS THEORY PHYS
description: Analytic functions, contour integrals and branch cuts. Conformal mapping. L aplace transforms. Asymptotic series and the gamma function. Green's functi ons.

title: COMPLEX VARIABLES
description: Analytic functions, contour integrals and branch cuts.   Conformal mapping. Fourier series and transforms. Laplace   transforms. Asymptotic series and the gamma function. Green's   functions.

title: LINEAR ALG AND APPS
description: Linear Algebra: vector spaces, operators, spectral   decomposition. Topics may include Sturm-Liouville equations,   special functions, group theory.

title: INT MECH & SPEC REL
description: Newtonian mechanics in 3D. Conservation laws. Complex numbers. Oscillations . Inertial reference frames, Lorentz transformations, relativistic momentum and energy, four-vectors.

title: ADVANCED MECHANICS
description: Calculus of variations. Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics. Central force problems and collision theory. Non-inertial reference frames. Coupled osci llations and waves.

title: NONLINEAR PHENOMENA
description: An introduction to nonlinear phenomena. Flows and   bifurcations in one and two dimensions, chaos, fractals,   strange attractors. Applications to phy sics, engineering,   chemistry, and biology.

title: ELECTROMAGNETISM
description: Electrostatics, Laplace's equation, method of images,   separation of variables, multipole expansion, magnetostatics,   electric and magnetic fields in matter.

title: ELECTROMAGNETISM
description: Electrodynamics, Maxwells equations, conservation laws,   electromagnetic waves, potentials and fields for moving   charges, radiation, special relativity.

title: QUANTUM MECHANICS
description: The postulates of quantum mechanics, the Schrödinger equation and its conse quences, the quantum harmonic oscillator and other one dimensional quantum systems, Hilbert Space and Dirac notation, the hydrogen atom.

title: QUANTUM MECHANICS
description: Spin and angular momentum, Clebsch-Gordan coefficients, identical particles , symmetries and conservation laws, time independent perturbation theory.

title: QUANTUM MECHANICS
description: The variational principle, time dependent perturbation theory, the adiabati c theorem. Topics from: WKB approximation, the Dirac equation, Berry's phas e, Bell's inequality, quantum cryptography, quantum computation.

title: THERMO & STAT PHYS
description: Principles of statistical physics, entropy, large numbers, thermodynamic pr inciples, microcanonical ensemble, ideal gas, free energy, chemical potenti al, selected applications.  Canonical ensemble, if time permits.

title: THERMO & STAT PHYS
description: Canonical ensemble and partition functions, grand canonical ensemble, quant um statistics, Fermi-Dirac, Bose-Einstein distribution laws. Topics from: B rownian motion, Langevin equation, dissipation and fluctuations, elementary kinetic theory, weakly interacting gases or mean field theory of magnetism , other topics illustrative of the breadth of the subject and/or selected a pplications.

title: CALIFORNIA PHYSICS
description: Why do the waves hit the beach every five seconds? This course teaches students the relevant fluid dynamics and allows them to apply it to natural phenomena of California: seismic waves, tsunamis, maximum tree heights, fluid flow around fish.

title: PRACTICE OF SCIENCE
description: Provides experience in pursuing careers within science and engineering through discussions with researchers, lectures on ethics, funding, intellectual property, and commercial innovation. Students prepare a focused research proposal that is pursued in the second quarter of the course.

title: COND MATT PHYS
description: CLASSIFICATION OF SOLIDS; CRYSTAL SYMMETRY, THERMAL ELECTRIC AND MAGNETIC PROPERTIES; METALS, SEMICONDUCTORS, AND THE BAND THEORY OF ELECTRONIC STATES; MAGNETIC RESONANCE; SUPERCONDUCTIVITY; IMPERFECTIONS. EMPHASIS WILL BE PLACED ON BOTH FUNDAMENTAL AND APPLIED ASPECTS.

title: COND MATT PHYS
description: CLASSIFICATION OF SOLIDS; CRYSTAL SYMMETRY, THERMAL ELECTRIC AND MAGNETIC P ROPERTIES; METALS, SEMICONDUCTORS, AND THE BAND THEORY OF ELECTRONIC STATES ; MAGNETIC RESONANCE; SUPERCONDUCTIVITY; IMPERFECTIONS. EMPHASIS WILL BE PLACED ON BOTH FUNDAMENTAL AND APPLIED ASPECTS.

title: PARTICLE PHYSICS
description: Introduction to quarks and leptons and the phenomenology of the particles they comprise; fundamental symmetries, invariance principles, and the associated quantum numbers, strong, electromagnetic, and weak interactions and their relationship.

title: ANALOG ELECTRONICS
description: Passive circuits, diodes, transistors, field effect   transistors, operatio nal amplifiers, feedback and control.   Design, building and testing of ana log circuits.

title: DIGITAL ELECTRONICS
description: GATES, COMBINATIONAL AND SEQUENTIAL LOGIC, MULTIPLEXERS, COUNTERS, SHIFT REGISTERS, MEMORY AND MICROPROCESSORS. DESIGN,   BUILDING AND TESTING OF DIGITAL CIRCUITRY, INCLUDING A MODERN   MICROPROCESSOR BASED COMPUTER SYSTEM.

title: ADVANCED LAB
description: Selected experiments in physics, i.e. saturated absorption spectroscopy, mu on lifetime measurements, pulsed nuclear magnetic resonance, Mossbauer effe ct. Develop skills in detailing observations in a scientific notebook, data collection and error analysis, operating complex physical apparatus, and s cientific communication.

title: ADVANCED LAB
description: Selected experiments in contemporary physics, e.g.,   holography, laser lig htscattering, optical pumping,   semiconductors, superconductivity, magneti c resonance,   Mossbauer effect.

title: INTRO SCI COMP
description: A survey of computers, programming, and computational techniques for the na tural sciences. Physical foundations of computation, binary arithmetic, com puter architecture, programming languages, operating systems, UNIX shell an d filesystems. Programming tools, variables and data structures, expression s, control flow, files, functions and scoping, objects, error handling, deb ugging, graphics, text processing, networking, data acquisition and transfe r. Mathematics and algorithms for data processing and analysis, numerical m ethods, random numbers and simulation.

title: GRAVITA-RELATIVITY
description: An introduction to Einstein's general relativity, the   spacetime of specia l relativity, the principle of   equivalence, gravity as geometry, the desc ription of   spacetime geometry, the spacetime of a relativistic star,   so lar system test of general relativity, gravitational   collapse, black hole s, cosmology.

title: STELLAR STRCTR/EVOL
description: Observed properties and classification of stars, the Hertzsprung-Russell di agram, stellar atmospheres, hydrostatic equilibrium, energy transport, equa tions of state, thermonuclear reaction rates, origin of the elements, life history of stars, stellar death, compact objects, star formation.

title: COSMOLOGY
description: The geometry, contents and evolution of the universe as a whole. The empiri cal and theoretical foundations for the Big Bang, the Hubble expansion, Fri edmann models, dark matter, dark energy, the thermal history of the univers e, the origin of the light elements, the cosmic microwave background, reion ization, and structure formation.

title: OBSER. ASTROPHYSICS
description: Techniques and implementation of observational methods in astronomy/astroph ysics. Sensors, digital-image processing and analysis, research projects wi th computer-controlled remote access telescope using a digital image sensor . Studies of   variable stars, galaxy morphology, supernovae, etc.

title: BIOPHYS & BIOMAT
description: Structure and function of cellular molecules (lipids, nucleic acids, proteins, and carbohydrates). Genetic engineering techniques of molecular biology. Biomolecular materials and biomedical applications (e.g., bio-sensors, drug delivery systems, gene carrier systems).

title: GALAXIES
description: The distribution of mass in galaxies, orbits of stars, Boltzmann equation, Jeans theorem, spiral structure & density waves, dynamics of star clusters, galaxy collisions, dynamical friction, gas dynamics, sound & shock waves, gas inflow & accretion, gas outflow & winds.

title: INTRO TO EXPER PHYS
description: Covers the essence of experimental research. Students study three different systems   experimentally, and write short Physical Review style articles a bout the results.   Students are responsible for deciding what to measure, how to analyze data, what   conclusions can be reached, etc.

title: INTRO TO EXPER PHYS
description: Covers the essence of experimental research. Students study three different systems experimentally, and write short Physical Review style articles abo ut the results.   Students are responsible for deciding what to measure, ho w to analyze data, what conclusions can be reached, etc.

title: HON EXPERIMENT PHYS
description: Computer control of experiments. Students learn LabView, and   use it to me asure and generate analog signals using a data   acquisition card and a per sonal computer. Students ultimately   use their computers to measure and co ntrol the temperature of   a copper rod.

title: HON EXPERIMENT PHYS
description: Computer control of experiments. Students learn LabView, and   use it to me asure and generate analog signals using a data   acquisition card and a per sonal computer. Students ultimately   use their computers to measure and co ntrol the temperature of   a copper rod.

title: HON EXPERIMENT PHYS
description: Design and construction of apparatus, drafting and computer-  aided design. Machine shop practice including use of all   major machine tools. The clas s acts as a team to design and,   time permitting, build a scientific appar atus for a campus   research group.

title: HON EXPERIMENT PHYS
description: Design and construction of apparatus, drafting and computer-  aided design. Machine shop practice including use of all   major machine tools. The clas s acts as a team to design and,   time permitting, build a scientific appar atus for a campus   research group.

title: OPTICS
description: Modern geometrical and physical optics. Polarization,   coherence, interference, and diffraction phenomena. Fourier   transform spectroscopy, intensity correlation interferometry,   spatial filtering, and holography. Selected topics on lasers,   light scattering, and quantum optics as time permits.

title: COND MATTER LAB
description: Offers qualified undergraduates the opportunity to work in research laboratories in condensed matter physics.

title: PARTICLE PHYS LAB
description: Offers qualified under graduates the opportunity to work in experimental research in elementary particle physics.

title: BIOPHYSICS LAB
description: Offers qualified undergraduates the opportunity to work in research laboratories in biophysics.

title: EXP RES IN ASTROPHY
description: Offers qualified undergraduates the opportunity to work in experimental research in astrophysics. Each staff member has his/her own course identified by a number listed in the schedule of classes.

title: SPEC TOP IN PHYS
description: Course varies from year to year according to the current interests.

title: UNDERGRAD SEMINAR
description: Selected topics of special interest designed to display the broad diversity of physics. Also designed to introduce students to faculty research and department labs.

title: PHYSICS OUTREACH
description: Active participation in at least 4 Circus events per   quarter but preferab ly all events. Improve an existing   Circus activity or create a new Circus activity for   evaluation by Physics Circus faculty and participants.

title: SCIENCE FOR PUBLIC
description: Provides experience in communicating science and technology to nonspecialists. The major components of the course are field work in mentoring, a biweekly seminar, presentations to precollege students and to adult nonscientists, and end-of-term research papers.

title: DIRECTED READING
description: Each staff member has own directed reading course identified by a number code listed in the schedule of classes.

title: RESEARCH IN PHYSICS
description: Directed individual study open to qualified seniors in the department. Each staff member has own independent studies course identified by a number code listed in the schedule of classes.

title: INDEPENDENT RESEARC
description: Undergraduate research for qualified seniors to gain valuable experience in research methodology.

title: BASIC PHYSICS
description: Rotational dynamics and angular momentum; equilibrium and   elasticity; per iodic motion including LRC electrical   circuits; gravitation; fluid mechan ics; temperature; thermal expansion; heat and the first law of thermodynami cs; heat conduction; kinetic theory of gases; entropy and the second law; h eat engines.

title: GEN PHYS
description: Classical mechanics, kinematics, vectors, Newton's laws, work and energy, c onservation laws. (F)

title: CLASSICAL MECHANICS
description: Review of lagrangian mechanics. Variational principles. Hamilton's equations. Canonical transformations. Hamilton Jacobi theory. Action angle variables. Time dependent and canonical perturbation theory. Central forces and scattering. Small vibrations. Rigid body motion. Poincare maps. Non-integrable systems. Hamiltonian and dissipative chaos.

title: EXPERIMENTAL PHYS
description: Introduction to Measurement and Experimentation. Basic good practices in no te-taking, data collection, data visualization, error estimation, error pro pagation, curve fitting, and drawing conclusions, all exercised in the cont ext of phenomena from mechanics and electronics.

title: EXPERIMENTAL PHYS
description: Introduction to Measurement and Experimentation, continued. Basics of image analysis, technical drawing, additive manufacturing, oscilloscope use, sea rching and digesting scientific literature, as well as continued practice o f skills introduced in 20AL in the context of electromagnetic and optical p henomena.

title: EXPERIMENTAL PHYS
description: Introduction to Measurement and Experimentation, with an emphasis on Scient ific Communication and Experimental Design. Searching the scientific litera ture, reading a scientific paper, proposing and executing a measurement, an d formally reporting on a measurement in writing, as well as continued prac tice of  skills introduced in 20AL and 20BL in the context of modern physic s phenomena.

title: GEN PHYS
description: Classical mechanics, kinematics, vectors, Newton's laws, work and energy, c onservation laws, rotational kinematics.

title: ELECTROMAG THEORY
description: Electrostatics, magnetostatics, boundary value problems, time varying fields, Maxwell's equations, radiation, multipole fields, scattering, relativistic particle dynamics.

title: ELECTROMAG THEORY
description: Electrostatics, magnetostatics, boundary value problems, time varying fields, Maxwell's equations, radiation, multipole fields, scattering, relativistic particle dynamics.

title: QUANTUM MECHANICS
description: Fundamental principles; Schroedinger equation; angular momentum; perturbati on theory; scattering theory, emission, and absorption of radiation; Dirac equation.

title: QUANTUM MECHANICS
description: Fundamental principles; Schroedinger equation; angular momentum; perturbation theory; scattering theory, emission, and absorption of radiation; Dirac equation.

title: QUANTUM MECHANICS
description: Fundamental principles; Schroedinger equation; angular momentum; perturbation theory; scattering theory, emission, and absorption of radiation; Dirac equation.

title: MANY BODY PROBLEM
description: Field theoretic methods as applied to (non-relativistic) condensed matter systems. Green's functions and diagrammatic techniques applied to various examples of interacting many body systems, including fermions, bosons, and spins. Relationship of theoretical quantities to physical measurements.

title: MANY BODY PROBLEM
description: Field theoretic methods as applied to (non-relativistic) condensed matter systems. Green's functions and diagrammatic techniques applied to various examples of interacting many body systems, including fermions, bosons, and spins. Relationship of theoretical quantities to physical measurements.

title: STATISTICAL MECH
description: Fundamental principles of classical and quantum statistics. Non-interacting Boltzmann, Bose, and Fermi systems. Virial   expansion and other approaches to interacting systems.   Phase transitions.

title: GEN PHYS
description: Rotational dynamics, fluid mechanics, gravitation, periodic motion, tempera ture and heat, thermodynamics.

title: ADVANCED STAT MECH
description: Course will cover some of the following topics: A) critical phenomena-phase diagrams, first and second order phase transitions, scaling theory, high-temperature expansions, renormalization group; B) nonequilibrium statistical mechanics-stochastic processes. Langevin equations, fluctuation-dissipation theorem, master equations, fluid dynamics.

title: REL QUANTUM FIELD
description: Introduction to the theory of Lorentz covariant quantized   fields. Global and local conservation laws. Path integral   formulation. Applications to q uantum electrodynamics, quantum   chromodynamics, and electroweak interacti ons. Other possible   topics include grand unification, the renormalization group,   anomolies, current algebra and supersymmetry.

title: REL QUANTUM FIELD
description: Introduction to the theory of Lorentz covariant quantized   fields. Global and local conservation laws. Path integral   formulation. Applications to quantum electrodynamics, quantum   chromodynamics, and electroweak interactions. Other possible   topics include grand unification, the renormalization group,   anomolies, current algebra and supersymmetry.

title: REL QUANTUM FIELD
description: Introduction to the theory of Lorentz covariant quantized   fields. Global and local conservation laws. Path integral   formulation. Applications to quantum electrodynamics, quantum   chromodynamics, and electroweak interactions. Other possible   topics include grand unification, the renormalization group,   anomolies, current algebra and supersymmetry.

title: CONCEPT COND MATTER
description: Lattice and electron dynamics. Elementary excitations and collective phenomena. Transport properties. Disorder and localization. Long-range order and broken symmetries. Magnetism, superconductivity and liquid crystals. Properties and structures of polymers, membranes, and self-assembling systems.

title: CONCEPT COND MATTER
description: Lattice and electron dynamics. Elementary excitations and collective phenomena. Transport properties. Disorder and localization. Long-range order and broken symmetries. Magnetism, superconductivity and liquid crystals. Properties and structures of polymers, membranes, and self-assembling systems.

title: CONCEPT COND MATTER
description: Lattice and electron dynamics. Elementary excitations and collective phenomena. Transport properties. Disorder and localization. Long-range order and broken symmetries. Magnetism, superconductivity and liquid crystals. Properties and structures of polymers, membranes, and self-assembling systems.

title: ELEM PARTICLE PHYS
description: The phenomenology of the standard model of particle   physics. QED and QCD process.

title: ELEM PARTICLE PHYS
description: Weak interactions; neutrino physics; C, P, and CP   violation; electroweak gauge theory and symmetry breaking.   Design of detectors and experiments; searches for new   phenomena.

title: ATOMIC & MOLEC PHYS
description: A survey of major topics in modern atomic physics. Topics in atomic structu re include general features of atomic spectra, fine structure, hyperfine st ructure, the Lamb shift, hydrogen, helium, alkali atoms, complex atoms, exc ited states, and synthetic atoms. Topics in atom-field interactions and ato m atom interactions include the DC Stark effect, the Zeeman effect, transit ions, two-level systems, stimulated and spontaneous emission, selection rul es, lifetimes, line shapes, broadening mechanisms, the AC Stark effect, mul tiphoton processes, scattering channels, and Feshbach resonances. Also cove rs  modern techniques including spectroscopy, laser cooling, atom traps, qu antum gases, cold molecules, trapped ions, and atomic clocks.

title: GAUGE THEORIES
description: Quantum theory of non-abelian gauge fields. Local, global, and spontaneous symmetry breaking. Collective phenomena; solitons, instantons, and magnetic monopoles. Effective field theories. Lattice gauge theory. applications to the standard model of elementary particles.

title: GAUGE THEORIES
description: Quantum theory of non-abelian gauge fields. Local, global, and spontaneous symmetry breaking. Collective phenomena; solitons, instantons, and magnetic monopoles. Effective field theories. Lattice gauge theory. Applications to the standard model of elementary particles.

title: GEN PHYS
description: Mechanical waves, sound, electric charge and electric field, Gauss' Law, el ectric potential, capacitance and dielectrics, current, resistance, electro motive force, DC circuits.

title: STRING THEORY
description: Introduction to string theory. Bosonic and super string theories and their spectra. String perturbation theory and conformal field theory. Nonlinear sigma models and spacetime structure. String compactifications and unification of forces. Non-perturbative results and methods; dualities and branes.

title: STRING THEORY
description: Introduction to string theory. Bosonic and super string theories and their spectra. String perturbation theory and conformal field theory. Nonlinear sigma models and spacetime structure. String compactifications and unification of forces. Non-perturbative results and methods; dualities and branes.

title: GENERAL RELATIVITY
description: Gravity as geometry, differential geometry, Einstein's equation, relativistic stars, gravitational collapse, black holes, cosmology, gravitational radiation, and special topics.

title: GENERAL RELATIVITY
description: Gravity as geometry, differential geometry, Einstein's equation, relativistic stars, gravitational collapse, black holes, cosmology, gravitational radiation, and special topics.

title: GENERAL RELATIVITY
description: Gravity as geometry, differential geometry, Einstein's equation, relativistic stars, gravitational collapse, black holes, cosmology, gravitational radiation, and special topics.

title: STLR STRCTR & EVOL
description: Physics of stellar structure, equations of state and heat transport. Birth of stars and physics of brown dwarfs. Thermonuclear burning and main sequence stellar structure. Evolution of stars and mass loss. Origin, physical structure, and cooling of compact objects.

title: INTERSTELLAR MEDIUM
description: Physical processes that regulate the state of diffuse gas in and around galaxies: Ionization and thermal equilibrium; absorption line studies; spectral line formation; properties of dust grains and extinction; molecular gas and star formation; supernova explosions and hydrodynamic shocks.

title: HIGH ENERY ASTRO
description: Accretion power in a range of astrophysical contexts, from quasars to galactic black holes. Rapid release of thermonuclear energy, Type I X-ray bursts, classical novae, Type Ia supernovae. Relativistic jets from black holes, non-thermal radiation processes, physics of gamma-ray bursts.

title: EXTRAGALACTIC ASTRO
description: Nebular astrophysics, active galactic nuclei, supermassive black holes, galaxies, clusters, dark matter, gravitational lensing, the intergalactic medium and galaxy formation.

title: COSMOLOGY
description: Friedmann models, distance measures, cosmological parameters, thermal history of the universe, cosmological density fields, structure formation (top-hat model, Press-Schechter), big bang nucleosynthesis, cosmic microwave background.

title: GALACTIC DYNAMICS
description: Stellar dynamics, Jeans equations, potential theory, orbit theory, linear stability analysis, kinetic theory, dynamical friction, applications to star clusters, galaxy morphology and mergers.

title: GEN PHYS
description: Magnetic fields, electromagnetic induction and inductance, AC circuits, Max well's equations, electromagnetic waves, light and geometrical optics, inte rference and diffraction.

title: PHYS STATS & DATA
description: A survey of statistical and machine learning techniques as applied in moder n physics research, with extensive applications to real data. Some of the t opics covered include Bayesian and frequentist approaches to statistics; fo rmulating and integrating likelihood functions; confidence intervals with a nd without assumptions of Gaussianity; Markov Chain Monte Carlo; principal component analysis and dimensionality reduction; Gaussian process regressio n; and time series analysis. Assignments will make use of published researc h and data sets, and will require the application of analysis techniques co vered in class.

title: GEN PHYS
description: Special relativity, blackbody radiation, Compton scattering, photoelectric effect, Bohr model, quantum mechanics, molecules, condensed matter, nuclear physics, elementary particles.

title: SPEC TOP IN PHYSICS
description: The course varies from year to year according to current interests.

title: EXPERIMENTAL PHYS
description: Covers the essence of experimental research. Students study atomic spectra, diffraction and basic quantum physics experimentally, and write short Phys ical Review style articles about their results.

title: COLLOQUIUM
description: Colloquium.

title: SEM GEN RELATIVITY
description: Talks on topics in gravity and general relativity pertinent to current doctoral research in the field.

title: SEM THEORETCL PHYS
description: Seminar in theoretical physics.

title: GRADUATE SEMINAR
description: Weekly seminar on topics of research currently being pursued in the departm ent of physics.

title: SEM ASTROPHYS COSMO
description: Talks on topics in astrophysics and cosmology pertinent to current doctoral research in the field.

title: PHYSICS OUTREACH
description: Active participation in an outreach program that presents physics demonstrations and experiments on the road to local schools in order to provide a valuable learning experience for K-12 students.

title: INTRO PROGRAM
description: An introduction to programming and data analysis for the physical sciences. Topics include syntax, good  coding practice, basic algorithmic structure , plotting, basic data analysis, numerical root-finding and integration.

title: BASIC PHYSICS
description: Mechanical waves, wave interference and normal modes, sound and hearing, el ectric field, Gauss's law, electric potential, capacitance and dielectrics, current, resistance, electromotive force, DC circuits.

title: PHYSICS LAB
description: Introductory laboratory emphasizing periodic motion, sound   and basic electronics.

title: BASIC PHYSICS
description: Magnetic fields, electromagnetic induction and inductance, AC circuits, Max well's equations, electromagnetic waves, light and geometrical optics, inte rference and diffraction.

title: ORIGINS
description: Introduction to the ways in which different disciplines have addressed the concept of origins. This course is organized as a dialogue between science, religion and history or more broadly construed between science and the hum anities.

title: PHYSICS LAB
description: Introductory laboratory emphasizing magnetism, circuits and optics.

title: BASIC PHYSICS
description: Special relativity, blackbody radiation, Compton scattering, photoelectric effect, Bohr model, quantum mechanics, molecules, condensed matter, nuclear physics, elementary particles.

title: TEACH ASSIST SEM
description: Covers development of teaching techniques especially oriented to lower-division physics laboratory instruction. Theoretical aspects covered at beginning of each quarter. Practical techniques discussed including weekly meeting with class instructor, formal evaluation, and videotaping analysis.

title: SPECIAL TOPICS
description: Special seminar on research subjects of current interest. Each staff member has a seminar identified by a number code listed in the schedule of classes.

title: GROUP STUDIES
description: Each staff member has a group studies course identified by a number code listed in the schedule of classes.

description: Individual tutorial. Reading and research in special topics including work done as the basis for the dissertation. Each staff member has a directed reading and research course identified by a number code listed in the schedule of classes.
